Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Weather Augmented Risk Determination System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project includes providing weather-related risk information to construction contracting companies, private farmers, insurance and re-insurance companies, risk management companies, local, federal agencies, state agencies, and any other company that may be impacted by adverse weather. This product provides insight into the impacts of adverse weather conditions, allowing its constituents to plan and prepare. Construction companies need to stay on schedule to avoid liquidated damages, so it is important to determine the impacts of weather on work stoppage, as well as decreased labor productivity. Insurance and risk management companies need information on the impacts of weather events on their constituents, to be able to competitively price their insurance policies. Furthermore, government agencies, such as the Departments of Transportation and Public Works need information on the impacts of weather on duration of their projects, to determine the best starting date for construction, considering impacts of weather on delays.

This I-Corps project provides a software tool (Weather Augmented Risk Determination System, WARDS) for estimating probabilities of work stoppage and labor productivity for each hour using long-term observations. WARDS provides both the likeliest delay (e.g., in days or months) and the likelihood that a user-defined addition of time for weather delay will actually occur. The research potential for this product include analyzing the differences in labor productivity and work stoppage across multiple locations. Furthermore, the technology platform can determine the historical observed changes in labor productivity and work stoppage. The product can determine the monetary impacts of changing labor productivity and work stoppage due to weather.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Currently, there is no commercially available tool to adjust construction scheduling based on weather conditions (e.g., temperature, soil moisture, wind shear, precipitation). Avoidable weather delays and schedule padding can cause developers and construction companies financial and reputational damage.

 

The Weather Augmented Risk Determination System (WARDS) is proprietary software that utilizes high quality, high resolution historical weather data, obtained from a wide range of sources to determine the expected weather delays based on the weather sensitivities of different construction tasks. A WARDS system user inputs relevant weather thresholds in which work can proceed (i.e. temperature between 40oF and 100oF, precipitation less than 0.2 in, and wind than 20 mi/hr), and the software gives the expected weather delays for each task, including the likelihood for each period of delay (day/week, etc.), the sum of which gives the expected weather delays for the entire project.

 

The broader impact of this project aims to minimize economic damage due to adverse weather in the construction industry, by quantifying the impacts of adverse weather on construction project schedules. Project managers and schedulers currently use online monthly temperature and precipitation averages to account for weather. They do not have a mechanism to convert weather information into delay information, and the information they use is often averaged over the month, unlike our hourly scale retrieved datasets.

 

Project managers need to stay on schedule for their company?s reputation and to avoid incurring liquidated damages. Through interviews with experts in the field, we determined that it is becoming increasingly necessary for project managers to have accurate schedules and that liquidated damages cost approximately 0.02% per day. This corresponds to approximately $1,000 per day for small projects and up to $50,000 per day for larger projects. Research shows that weather impacts are reported to be one of the biggest factors that cause cost overruns and delays in construction projects.

 

The NSF I-Corps program provided the opportunity to meet and discuss with over 100 general contractors, consultants, project managers, and schedulers across the United States to determine if this product was business worthy. The meetings resulted in constructive feedback, leading to improvements in the algorithm of the product.

 

The lessons learned from this project were that although the software is useful, and necessary in the field, schedulers would not spend the time to input the information to receive the accurate estimates of weather-related delays.
